Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2012 07:49PM howhm02l wrote: Gamergirl - I am 40 and within the past 2 weeks have been diagnosed with DCIS (Pre-surgery) and BRCA2 positive. I am I the midst of trying to schedule surgeries now. Had an appt with BS and GO. Have appt with PS on Monday. How long after our BMX did you have the hysterectomy?
Posts.Title: Prophylactic hysterectomy/oopherectomy jessica749 howhm02l

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2012 11:32AM howhm02l wrote: I am not as nervous about the surgery itself or even the recovery.  I'm too focused on the final pahtology report.  My DCIS lesion is big - 8 cm x 3 cm x 2 cm, and even though the biolpsy revealed DCIS, stage 2, I'm afraid there's IDC in there as well.  I watched my mom go through chemo when I was 10, and I vividly remember how sick she was.  I think the fear of my children seeing me sick and being as worried as I was 30 years ago is stronger than the fear of me going through chemo myself - if that makes any sense.  I have not had trouble sleeping, but I have a cold so I've taken nyquil the past couple of nights . . . I must get back to work so I'm sorry I can't do personal hellos to everyone now - will stop in again tonight. Tazzy - thank you for the welcome.  Shabby - I am having BMX, and the right side is prophylactic.  My mom was diagnosed at 34, and her sister was 42.  I am 40.  I had decided when they came out with the genetic testing (in 1995, I think) that I would have BMX if I tested positive.  Unfortunately, DCIS was detected on MRI (confirmed with mammorgram and biopsy) before I was able to get the testing done!  I now know that I am BRAC2+ and did not blink at the decision to do BMX.  Although I have to admit that it would be a tougher decision if it were not for the DCIS diagnosis. Omeggo - I'm also planning to hit the gym pretty hard in the next month.  I want to try and be as fit (which is a LONG way off for me - I sit at a desk all day, every day) as possible before surgery, especially if they are able to do my DIEP 2 weeks after the BMX I think it helps with the healing process. Beckers - I LOVE the idea of renting the chair after my DIEP (assuming I do not need rads or chemo after BMX).  I wonder if they could/would take it up stairs to our bonus room . . .
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Seriously, now? The dog who so patiently sat with me constantly when I was on bed rest for weeks seven years ago. Seriously? I am so angry and sad! Thanks for letting me vent. I know it may seem trivial to be so upset about this in light of everything else, but it is heartbreaking, truly heartbreaking. Heather

Tazzy - I am so glad you got you date.  Thoughts and prayers for you for next week!  Leah and Mcc - I am so sorry you have had to join us. Hard to believe August is almost here.  I think I'm just still in denial.  I'm starting to get concerned about the recovery - reading posts, etc.  It's a fine line between reading what is necessary to be prepared and crossing into information overload and complete hysteria!
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2012 06:34PM howhm02l wrote: Marilyn - awesome news. You are an inspiration! Trinity - I am so sorry. Not something you need to have laid on you right now, at all. Damiana and Tazzy - warm thoughts and prayers for tomorrow. Beckers - I absolutely remember your concerns. I am with you in that I try to "prepare" myself for the worst so I am not surprised or caught off guard. As others have said, there are so many things that could cause a shadow or spot to appear on x-ray. A couple of weeks ago, I read a quotation from Michael J. Fox on this site: “Don’t spend a lot of time imagining worst-case scenario. It rarely goes down as you imagine it will, and if by some fluke it does, you will have lived it twice.” I am not a quotation sort of person and am not at all trying to minimize your concern, but I pass that along because it did help me think that my attempts at preparing myself do not accomplish much. I will be praying for a clean CT on Monday and for peace of mind as you wait.

Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2012 06:57AM howhm02l wrote: For all the ladies receiving chemo - you are in my constant thoughts and prayers.  I wish for minimal and SEs and strength for each of you. Melmcbee - I hate to hear all that you are going through with your family.  I will be praying for strength and peace. Waterpolomom - I was interested to read about you going back to work.  I have been working from home for the past few weeks, but am planning to go back into the office in a couple of weeks.  I'm nervous about it! Bras - I went to my local mastectomy shop to be fitted for an LE prevention sleeve, and the employee told me that any woman who has had breast cancer surgery receives 4 bras per year that must be covered by insurance.  Please go visit your local shop to be fitted! Help with Family Issue - I think most of you know that my mother passed away from BC at 38, when I was 14.  My dad remarried shortly thereafter, and for the past 27 years, my stepmother has been a complete nightmare - a bully, insecure, emotionally abusive, makes EVERY situation about herself, completely obsessed with us viewing her as "our mother," which she is not.   Anyway, we had a big family blowup on Saturday (we all live within 15 minutes of each other) because she accused my sister and me of not thinking about her enough.  For example, she accused my sister of being selfish because my sister did not talk to her enough, hug her, etc. on the day of my BMX.  Seriously?  Accused my sister, who's mother, aunt, and sister all have had BC of not thinking about the stepmother the day of my BMX. Then, she accused me of not being thoughtful for not calling her enough and inviting her to do things. I told her I had been a little preoccupied because I have BC.  Her response, "No, you don't - not anymore."  I understand that I had DCIS and that it was removed in my BMX, but in my mind, it will always be there due to the risk of recurrence (although I understand it is a small risk).  Plus, I'm BRCA positive so I have an ongoing increased risk of developing any number of ther cancers.  I guess it bothered me coming from her because given her background of sociopathic behavior, it was basically a statement that none of it ever happened - and a warning that it should never be mentioned again.  Thanks for letting me vent.  It really helps.
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2012 01:31PM howhm02l wrote: Argh - just need to vent!  Since I am BRCA2+, I have 25% risk for ovarian cancer.  I had an ultrasound on Friday to make sure everything was okay.  Planning to have a ooph and hysterectomy at some point once the BMX and reconstruction are behind me. I called the GO's office today to get results.  The nurse called back and said the report was on the doc's desk, that the doc was out of clinic this week, and that they would call me next Monday.  Seriously?  I asked if there was someone else who could review to give me the results, and she said no - it will be next Monday, at least.  Seriously?   I am on vacation next week at the beach.  I don't want to be waiting for a phone call. I do not have any family history of ovarian cancer so I'm not completely freaking out like I was after the breast testing, but it is my medical record.  It absolutely baffles me that I can't get a copy of it.

For me, I think the wait between the surgery and that pathology will be overwhelming. August sisters - I have not had any trouble sleeping until this week, but my brain is on cancer and surgery overdrive. I do not know what I would do without all of you. Thank you so much for being here. Heather

The drains are driving me nuts. Surgery was 10 days ago but left side is still at 35 or 40 cc so not likely to be coming out before DIEP on Thursday. Argh - the thoughts of another r surgery just 4 days from now is enough to send me over the edge. Just wondering if anyone else has had this? I have not had any post op appt because I have the next surgery this week. Final complaint - my chest and back muscles are so tight! Justine graciously emailed me her exercises because I was not given anything due to upcoming DIEP. I am hoping they will help. Thank you all so much for listening, being there, and helping. I feel better already just "talking" about it.

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2012 06:46PM howhm02l wrote: 301724 - glad to hear things are going well. It is definitely a process. I met with PS today for second post op. He said everything looks great. Wants to wait until my open wounds heal (where stitches dissolved) before scheduling Stage II. He thinks all we will need to do at Stage II is niple construction and a little lipo on the side of each beast to remove some excess tissue. Right now there is a triangular bump on the outside of each breast, but otherwise the girls look good now! Great cleavage and very soft. Best news though is he agreed that I can have ooph during the same surgery. Is it possible I cold have just one day surgery left in this journey? I hope you are all doing well.

The bras they sell do have the pocket, but it was not noticeable. There were some really pretty ones that seemed very supportive without wire. I went to get measured for sleeve yesterday for prevention. Left arm measures between 1/2 and 1 cm larger so I am going for LE screening today. Do you ever feel like it is all never ending!?!
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2012 05:46AM howhm02l wrote: Cottontail - YES!!!!!!! I am one week post Bilateral DIEP, and the most painful part of my body is my upper left drain. It pulls and stings and sends shooting pains all down my left side. All the service providers say it looks fine, but I know something is going on. Thank you for your post. I know I am not alone! And if you find any miracle cure,please pass along. I have been home for 2 days now. 7 nights in the hosptial was just brutal - all the poking and prodding. I feel better every day. I know I will really feel better once I get these 4 drains out. I have a follow up apt with my BS on Tuesday, and hope she will give give the okay to remove them and does dot want to defer to PS.
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2012 01:40PM howhm02l wrote: So good to hear from folks today - you have all been so important to me. Even if we are not posting as much, I know we think of each other often. Beckers - my tummy is pretty flat, which has made me notice my thighs, hips, and back! :)
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2012 07:29PM howhm02l wrote: Beckers- I am with you! All sorts of itching in numb areas. It is really driving me nuts! Gma- I will try the hydrocortisone for this annoying itching. I am working a bit from home but am hesitant to go into the office for fear of springing a leak that I am unaware of because I am numb in all the areas that would leak! I worry I would not notice it until I was covered in fluid.
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2012 04:56PM howhm02l wrote: Thank you all so much for your kind words and hugs! Shabby - I had my Pre-op visit last week. They did a chest X-ray, EKG, drew 3 vials of blood, and did a complete medical history. I hope that helps. Prayes and good thoughts!!!
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2012 06:47PM howhm02l wrote: Marilyn - I got excited for you as I raed your post. My chest has got bigger with each child, and I have to admit that I am looking forward to something much smaller. I am just hopeful that my reconstruction can come sooner rather than later depending on the pathology. Why did you have a mammogram last week, just curious? Omeggo and Shabby - I was planning to step up my gym efforts -(from 3 to 5 days each week) to assist with recovery, but my precious 4 year old graciously shared her cold, and the congestion and cough have completely wiped me out. I have to admit that I have not thought too much about the 16th. Like Sahbby, I am worried most about the following week and the pathology results. Now, I am trying to get things wrapped up at work, we go on vacation to the beach the week of the 5th, school starts soon, etc. I am very grateful to have those distractions. I think it helps makes the time pass by more quickly. Plus, because I am BRCA2+ and have an increased risk for Ovarian cancer, I have an ultrasound on Friday to make sure all is well there. The gynecological oncologist has recommended that ovaries, tubes, uterus, and cervix all come out once the beast cancer issue is under control. The BMX is not as scary to me as removing everything else. I am only 40 (never thought I would say that!) and fear menopause and the loss of sex drive. No one in my family has ever had ovarian cancer so I don't fear it as much as I have always feared breast cancer, but since there are no symptoms and no wall way to screen, I do not feel like I can risk waiting too long. Thinking good thoughts for us as August approaches, Heather
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2012 06:16AM howhm02l wrote: Tomorrow is August 1 - I cannot believe it.  Quick update on the pelvic ultrasound - a good friend is a family medicine doctor.  I called and had him added as a treating physician so they faxed him the ultrasound results.  Ovaries look good! At least I can cross that off the list of worries for now.  I also asked by BS to refer me to a different GO.  When I went to the first GO, who is supposed to be the best in town, she did an exam, ordered the ultrasound and blood test, and said if you are finished with your family, we need to take everything out - call her office to schedule as early as 6 weeks after the BMX and reconstruction.  No discussion of risk of developing ovarian cancer (other than the 25% that is tied to the BRCA2+ positive status), no discussion of family history - no one in my family has had ovarian cancer, no discussion of side effects related to ovary removal since I'm (only) 40, the fact that I'm surely not a candidate for any HRT due to BRCA2+ status even if I am having BMX.  Don't get me wrong - I know I don't want to mess with ovarian cancer because it is completely silent, and I know that ooph is the best method of preventing.  I just want to know what I'm getting into by having ANOTHER surgery - as if the two major surgeries I have scheduled for August (BMX on 8/16 and DIEP on 8/30) aren't enough already.  Thank you all so much for letting me talk through this! Onelife - Welcome.  This is a fabulous group of women.
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2012 11:02AM howhm02l wrote: Market - glad to hear things went well! Just - I love the image of your dad sewing zippers onto tanks. :) Funny thing happened this morning-you may remember last week when the GO office would not give me ovarian ultrasound results because the doc was out of the office. Anyway the nurse called this morning to tell me the results were fine. The funny part was when she said she was calling from Dr. Williams' office, and I had to think, - now which one is that? Ha! You know you are a cancer patient when ou cannot keep all your doctors straight. Heather
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2012 07:44PM howhm02l wrote: So much wisdom on this board tonight. Thank you all so much. I truly feel blessed to have you all in my life to help put everything in perspective. Trinity - I am so sorry about your mom! Leah - I think it is wonderful that you are participating in the clinical research programs. It is only because of research that we face the positive outlook we have today in comparison to what my mother faced 20 years ago. I am BRCA2+ so in addition to the BMX, I am also looking at an ooph soon. I am 40, and I am concerned about the early menopause. I think I am more attached to my ovaries than my breasts! I have a vaginal ultrasound tomorrow just to make sure there is not anything happening with the ovaries. Now as I go to bed, I will repeat the Marilyn and Tazzy mantra - in 6 months, in 6 months.

MRI Radiology report shows clumped non- mass like enhancement 5 cm x 4 cm x 2 cm with mixed kinetics including rapid washout. Bi-Rad of 4. I have a biopsy scheduled for 6/26. I had blood drawn for BRCA test on 6/21. I am scared. Thank you. Dx 6/28/2012, DCIS, 6cm+, Stage 0, Grade 2, 0/4 nodes Surgery 8/16/2012 Mastectomy: Left, Right Surgery 8/30/2012 Reconstruction (left): DIEP flap; Reconstruction (right): DIEP flap Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Biopsy On Tuesday and Waiting for BCRA results howhm02l howhm02l

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2012 12:57AM howhm02l wrote: This is a fascinating post. I was just diagnosed at 40. I am BRCA2+. My mother was 34, and her sister was 42 (it was not until I was diagnosed that I learned she was 42- I had always thought she was post- menopausal). Anyway, I am interested in how many women who were younger than 40 had a family history and whether the BRCA test had been recommended prior to your diagnosis. Even with my positive BRCA2 test, my DCIS diagnosis, and out mother and aunt's BC, my sister's ob/gym office was completely clueless in how to get her tested. They still haven't figured out how to ask for "short form" test to see if she is positive for my mutation. I had the genetic counseling a few years ago and just had not done the testing yet in part out of concern that the results would make me uninsurable. I know I am fortunate that a routine MRI caught my tumor at the DCIS stage, and I had the MRI done as part of my routine screens. I have had mammograms since I was 24. I wonder how many people with family history are being told about BRCA testing by their regular ob/gyns? I know that my daughter, who is now only 4 years old, will need to get tested at some point, maybe 18? I am sorry for the rambling - thanks for listening.
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2012 04:45PM howhm02l wrote: Kam170 - Thanks for the response - it just astounds me!  I understand that BRCA cancers make up only a relatively small percentage of BC, but if you knew you could eliminate it or at least greatly diminish it in that population, why would you not recommend testing?  The genetics counselor I met with a few years ago asked the same thing, what would you do differently - I think it is nearly impossible to answer that question in the abstract.  My sister has a friend who's mother AND grandmother had BC and no one has even suggested that she see a geneticist.   I did not necessarily mean to limit requests to people 40 and under - sorry it read that way.  I included that only because 40 has been the age when they recommend mammo so if you are not having them before then and have one of the BRCA genes unknowingly then you would be completely in the dark until you find a lump.   I hope your GF never has to face this.
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2012 11:51PM howhm02l wrote: Totally worth a few bad days! When I think about the changes and advances in the past 30 years since my mom was diagnosed - just imagine what can happen in the next 30. Thank you all. I feel so fortunate to have found this group of strong women.
Posts.Title: Need support having a pbmx on August 8th and I am scared Pointvalue camillegal

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2012 04:01PM howhm02l wrote: Elise - I am BRCA2+ (was tested right before biopsy) and lost my mother to breast cancer when I was 14, and she was 38.  I ache with you for my mother, for my daughter, who is only 4 years old, and for my sister who is about to be tested for BRCA at 36.  The hardest part for me about all of this has been reliving the four years my mom was sick from when I was 10-14.  I have days that I am that terrified 10 year old all over again. I think you and Shabby are so brave to have a PBMX.  In a way I feel like my decision has been somewhat easier because I do have DCIS in the left. The ooph that has been recommended has been tougher because my ovaries, at least for now, "look great" on ultrasound. I fear the recovery from the BMX (8/16) and reconstruction (8/30) and the pathology report, but I know that I am fortunate that it has been caught so early in me.  I just hope that by the time my daughter is old enough to be tested for BRCA, they will have figured out a way to fix that genetic mutuation so that she won't be faced with testing and biopsy and surgery and pathology and all the waiting in between.
Posts.Title: Need support having a pbmx on August 8th and I am scared Pointvalue camillegal

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2012 04:11PM howhm02l wrote: I am 41. I had a routine screening MRI in June due to family history. My MRI had an area of non-mass enhancement that did turn out to be DCIS. I was able to have stereotactic biopsy. During the mammogram for the biopsy, there were extensive calcifications, which had not appeared on a mammogram just 9 months before - CRAZY, I know. It may be worth a second opinion from another radiologist. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Tomorrow - Strong Family History - Scared howhm02l Beckers

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2012 05:14PM howhm02l wrote: Update - they did a mammogram this morning and were able to see calcifications in the area identified in the MRI. This allowed them to do a stereotactic biopsy instead of MRI biopsy. The doctor was concerned about the size of the area because I had a mammogram in September, which was clear. He said statistically, my films would point toward DCIS. He expects pathology report by Friday. BDavis - I had blood drawn last week for BRAC testing. They said it would be 2-3 weeks. Thank you all. I will post when I get path results.

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2012 03:50PM howhm02l wrote: I recieved the biopsy results today - DCIS intermediate grade - non-invasive.  The radiologist who performed the biopsy and reviewed the mammograms from Tuesday said the area is larger than it was on the MRI two weeks ago when it measured 5 cm x 4 cm x 2 cm. I appreciate the advice regarding waiting for BRCA results before making decisions.  I had decided years ago that at the first hint of any problem I would have BMX.   I have an appointment with the surgeon on Monday.   Thank you all!  Support and understanding are incredible.
